intro: Welcome, young scientists! Today we're going to explore the amazing world of metals and non-metals through an interactive simulation. Get ready to discover how these materials behave differently when we test their properties!

questions.question: When you look at the metal sample in the simulation, what do you notice about its appearance compared to the non-metal sample?
options: A) The metal appears dull while the non-metal looks shiny
B) Both samples look equally dull and rough
C) The metal appears shiny and lustrous while the non-metal looks dull
D) Both samples look equally shiny and smooth
questions.hint: Look closely at the left and right samples in the simulation. Which one reflects light more brightly?
questions.explanation: Metals are typically lustrous (shiny) because they reflect light well, while non-metals usually have a dull appearance. This is one of the key physical properties that helps us identify them!

questions.question: What happens when you try to hammer the metal sample flat in the simulation?
options: A) It cracks and breaks into pieces
B) It flattens into a thin sheet without breaking
C) It melts and becomes liquid
D) It stays exactly the same shape
questions.hint: Try clicking the hammer button on the metal sample. Does it bend or break?
questions.explanation: This demonstrates malleability - the ability of metals to be hammered into thin sheets without breaking. This property is why we can make aluminum foil from metal!

questions.question: Where in everyday life would you most likely use a metal's ability to conduct electricity?
options: B) Creating electrical wires in your house
questions.hint: Think about what materials carry electricity to power your lights and devices
questions.explanation: Metals like copper are excellent conductors of electricity, which is why they're used in electrical wiring throughout homes and buildings. This allows electricity to flow safely and efficiently!

followups: Try setting both the hammer and wire-stretching tools on the metal sample. What do you notice about how it behaves differently from the non-metal?
Can you find which sample conducts heat better by watching the animated flow indicators?
Challenge: Predict which sample will break when you try to bend it, then test your prediction!
summary: Great job exploring the properties of metals and non-metals! Remember, metals are typically shiny, can be hammered flat (malleable), stretched into wires (ductile), and conduct electricity well. Non-metals are usually dull, brittle, and poor conductors. These properties help us choose the right materials for different jobs!
